title: Corticobasal Degeneration (CBD) / Corticobasal Syndrome (CBS)
scope: ** Evaluation and symptomatic management of corticobasal syndrome (CBS) and pathologically confirmed corticobasal degeneration (CBD). Covers diagnostic criteria (Armstrong 2013), distinguishing CBS from other underlying pathologies presenting as CBS (AD, PSP, FTD), and symptomatic treatment of rigidity, myoclonus, dystonia, limb apraxia, and behavioral/cognitive symptoms. Excludes other parkinsonian syndromes as primary diagnosis but includes them in differential.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Electrolytes, renal/hepatic function; metabolic causes of encephalopathy
Thyroid disease as treatable contributor to cognitive/motor symptoms
B12 deficiency as treatable cause of cognitive impairment and myelopathy
Neurosyphilis as treatable cause of progressive dementia with movement disorder

Extended Labs (Rule Out Treatable Mimics.rationale: Wilson disease if age <50 with dystonia and cognitive decline
Autoimmune encephalitis; CNS vasculitis; systemic inflammatory disease

Extended Labs (Rule Out Treatable Mimics.item: Paraneoplastic antibody panel (CASPR2, LGI1, NMDAR, CRMP5)
Extended Labs (Rule Out Treatable Mimics.rationale: Autoimmune encephalitis presenting as CBS; especially if subacute onset or younger age
Genetic prion disease (GSS, FFI) presenting as CBS
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in rapidly progressive CBS

Rare/Specialized (Research/Emerging Biom.rationale: Differentiate AD pathology presenting as CBS (high p-tau/Aβ42 ratio) from non-AD CBS
Rare/Specialized (Research/Emerging Biom.target: AD pattern: low Aβ42, high p-tau; non-AD: normal Aβ42

Rare/Specialized (Research/Emerging Biom.rationale: Marker of neurodegeneration severity; prognostic value
Distinguish AD-CBS (amyloid positive) from true CBD (amyloid negative)
Rare/Specialized (Research/Emerging Biom.target: Negative amyloid PET supports CBD; positive suggests AD-CBS

Rare/Specialized (Research/Emerging Biom.rationale: Research biomarker; 4R tauopathies may show asymmetric cortical uptake
FTD-related genes if family history or young onset

Essential/First-line.target: Asymmetric cortical atrophy (parietal, frontal) contralateral to more affected limb; may be normal early

Essential/First-line.timing: ED acute presentation; exclude stroke, hemorrhage, mass
Essential/First-line.target: No acute lesion; may show asymmetric atrophy

Extended.timing: Outpatient; supports diagnosis; high diagnostic value
Extended.target: Asymmetric frontoparietal hypometabolism contralateral to most-affected side; basal ganglia hypometabolism

Extended.timing: Differentiate CBS from essential tremor or functional movement disorder
Extended.target: Asymmetrically reduced dopamine transporter uptake contralateral to more affected side

Extended.timing: Characterize cognitive profile; quantify apraxia, executive dysfunction, visuospatial deficits
Extended.target: Asymmetric cortical deficits (apraxia, visuospatial > memory); executive dysfunction

Extended.timing: Myoclonus characterization; exclude seizures; CJD evaluation (periodic complexes)
Extended.target: Normal background or asymmetric slowing; no periodic sharp wave complexes (which suggest CJD)

Extended.timing: If dysphagia present; baseline and serial assessment

Rare/Specialized.timing: Differentiate AD-CBS from CBD-CBS; important for clinical trial eligibility
Rare/Specialized.target: Negative in CBD; positive in AD-CBS

Rare/Specialized.timing: Research; asymmetric cortical tau deposition supports 4R tauopathy
Only if peripheral neuropathy suspected as confounding factor
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal (no peripheral neuropathy expected in CBD)

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Therapeutic trial for parkinsonism/rigidity; most CBS patients have poor or absent levodopa response but trial is recommended for diagnosis and potential modest benefit

dosing.instructions: Start carbidopa-levodopa 25/100 mg TID; titrate to 25/250 mg TID over 4-6 weeks; adequate trial = 1000 mg levodopa daily for ≥2 months; most CBS patients show minimal response

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Concurrent non-selective MAOIs; narrow-angle glaucoma; melanoma (historical, debated)
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Orthostatic BP; nausea; dyskinesias; hallucinations; impulse control behaviors

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Musculoskeletal pain from dystonia and rigidity; safer than NSAIDs in elderly

dosing.instructions: 500-1000 mg PO q6h as needed; max 3000 mg/day in elderly; max 4000 mg/day in younger adults

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; active liver disease
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Hepatic function; total daily dose including combination products

Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.indication: Cortical myoclonus; often prominent and disabling in CBS

dosing.instructions: Start 0.25-0.5 mg BID; titrate by 0.5 mg q3-7d; max 4 mg/day; use lowest effective dose to avoid sedation

Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; acute narrow-angle glaucoma; severe respiratory insufficiency
Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.monitoring: Sedation; fall risk; respiratory depression (especially with opioids); cognitive worsening; dependence

Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.indication: Cortical myoclonus; fewer sedation effects than clonazepam

dosing.instructions: Start 250-500 mg BID; titrate by 250-500 mg q1-2wk; max 3000 mg/day

Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust); suicidal ideation
Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.monitoring: Mood changes (irritability, depression); sedation; renal function for dose adjustment

Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.indication: Cortical myoclonus refractory to clonazepam and levetiracetam

dosing.instructions: Start 250 mg BID; titrate to 500-750 mg BID; therapeutic level 50-100 mcg/mL; max 60 mg/kg/day

Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.contraindications: Hepatic disease; pregnancy (teratogenic); urea cycle disorders; mitochondrial disease (POLG mutations)
Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.monitoring: LFTs; CBC; ammonia level; drug levels; weight; tremor; thrombocytopenia

Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.indication: Focal dystonia; painful limb dystonia; especially hand/arm dystonia which is common in CBS

doseOptions.orderSentence: Botulinum toxin type A (onabotulinumtoxinA) 10-50 units per muscle IM

dosing.instructions: Dose varies by muscle; hand/finger extensors 10-20 units per muscle; biceps 50-100 units; effect onset 3-7 days; repeat q12 weeks; EMG guidance recommended
dosing.orderSentence: Botulinum toxin type A (onabotulinumtoxinA) 10-50 units per muscle IM

Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.contraindications: Myasthenia gravis; Lambert-Eaton; infection at injection site
Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.monitoring: Excessive weakness at injection site; dysphagia if neck muscles injected; antibody formation reducing efficacy

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg TID; titrate by 5 mg/dose q3-5d; max 80 mg/day; do NOT discontinue abruptly (withdrawal seizures)

Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.contraindications: Severe renal impairment; epilepsy (relative — lower seizure threshold)
Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.monitoring: Sedation; weakness; dizziness; GI symptoms; withdrawal risk

Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.indication: Rigidity and spasticity; alternative to baclofen

dosing.instructions: Start 2 mg at bedtime; titrate by 2-4 mg q3-7d; max 36 mg/day divided TID

Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.contraindications: Concurrent use of fluvoxamine or ciprofloxacin (potent CYP1A2 inhibitors); severe hepatic impairment
Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.monitoring: LFTs at baseline, 1, 3, 6 months then periodically; sedation; hypotension; dry mouth

Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.indication: Neuropathic or musculoskeletal pain from dystonia and rigidity

dosing.instructions: Start 300 mg qHS; titrate by 300 mg q1-3d; max 3600 mg/day divided TID

Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.indication: Depression; anxiety; apathy (may partially respond); behavioral symptoms

dosing.instructions: Start 25-50 mg daily; titrate by 25-50 mg q2-4wk; max 200 mg daily

Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.monitoring: Suicidality in first weeks; serotonin syndrome; bleeding risk; QTc at higher doses

dosing.instructions: Start 5-10 mg daily; max 20 mg daily

Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; QT prolongation; concurrent pimozide
Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.monitoring: QTc (especially >10 mg or with other QT-prolonging drugs); suicidality; serotonin syndrome

Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.indication: Insomnia; agitation; sleep disturbance common in CBS

dosing.instructions: Start 25-50 mg qHS; titrate to 100-150 mg qHS; lower doses for sleep, higher for behavioral symptoms

Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.indication: Cognitive impairment; especially if AD pathology suspected (AD-CBS)

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg daily at bedtime; increase to 10 mg daily after 4-6 weeks; limited evidence in pure CBD; more helpful if underlying AD

Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.contraindications: Severe bradycardia; active peptic ulcer; COPD (relative)
Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.monitoring: GI symptoms (nausea, diarrhea); bradycardia; insomnia; weight loss; heart rate

Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.indication: Hallucinations; psychosis; severe agitation; behavioral disturbance

dosing.instructions: Start 12.5-25 mg qHS; titrate slowly by 12.5-25 mg q3-7d; max 200 mg/day; lowest effective dose

Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.contraindications: Dementia-related psychosis (FDA black box); severe hepatic impairment; QT prolongation
Symptomatic/Maintenance Treatment.monitoring: Metabolic (glucose, lipids, weight); EPS (though lowest risk among antipsychotics); QTc; sedation; orthostatic BP

Prophylactic/Preventive Treatment.indication: Osteoporosis prevention given high fall risk and limited mobility

doseOptions.orderSentence: Calcium + Vitamin D 600 mg calcium + 1000 IU D3 PO

dosing.instructions: Calcium carbonate 600 mg BID with meals + Vitamin D3 1000-2000 IU daily; total 1200 mg calcium/day
dosing.orderSentence: Calcium + Vitamin D 600 mg calcium + 1000 IU D3 PO

Prophylactic/Preventive Treatment.monitoring: Calcium level, Vitamin D level annually; renal function

Prophylactic/Preventive Treatment.indication: Dysphagia with thin liquid aspiration on swallow study

doseOptions.orderSentence: Thickened liquids Per SLP recommendation PO

dosing.instructions: Nectar-thick, honey-thick, or pudding-thick per swallow study results; reassess as disease progresses
dosing.orderSentence: Thickened liquids Per SLP recommendation PO

Prophylactic/Preventive Treatment.monitoring: Weight, hydration status, aspiration events; serial swallow evaluations

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consultation for acute presentations; movement disorders specialist/behavioral neurologist for diagnostic confirmation, levodopa trial, and long-term symptomatic management
Neuropsychological testing to characterize cognitive profile (apraxia, executive, visuospatial) and differentiate from AD or FTD
Physical therapy for mobility, fall prevention, gait training, and range of motion exercises for dystonic limbs
Occupational therapy for adaptive equipment, hand function strategies, and activities of daily living assistance given limb apraxia and alien limb
Speech-language pathology for evaluation of dysarthria, dysphagia screening (VFSS or FEES), and communication strategies as disease progresses
Psychiatry for management of depression, anxiety, apathy, and behavioral symptoms common in CBS
Palliative care consultation for goals of care discussion, advance care planning, and symptom management as disease progresses
Social work for caregiver support, home health services, disability applications, and community resource coordination
Nutrition/Dietitian for caloric optimization, texture-modified diet guidance, and nutritional support planning
Genetic counseling if family history suggests hereditary frontotemporal dementia (MAPT, GRN, C9orf72 mutations)

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Use fall precautions at all times including grab bars, non-slip mats, and removing tripping hazards given asymmetric weakness, rigidity, and impaired balance
Report worsening swallowing difficulty, choking episodes, or recurrent coughing during meals (aspiration risk increases with disease progression)
Engage in advance care planning discussions early while decision-making capacity is preserved, including healthcare proxy and living will

Return to ED if sudden worsening of symptoms, new fever, fall with head injury, or inability to swallow (may indicate stroke, infection, aspiration, or medication side effect rather than disease progression)
Do not expect dramatic improvement from levodopa — CBS typically shows poor response, but trial is important for diagnosis and modest benefit is possible
Do NOT stop clonazepam, baclofen, or other prescribed medications abruptly without physician guidance (risk of withdrawal symptoms)
Alien limb movements are part of the disease and are not dangerous; strategies to manage include placing the affected hand in a pocket or holding an object
Contact CurePSP (curepsp.org) and AFTD (theaftd.org) for patient and caregiver support resources specific to atypical parkinsonian syndromes

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular physical activity including assisted exercises to maintain joint mobility and prevent contractures in dystonic limbs
Home safety evaluation to remove fall hazards and install adaptive equipment (grab bars, raised toilet seat, shower chair)
Aspiration precautions including texture-modified diet as recommended by speech therapy; upright positioning during meals; small bites and adequate time for meals
Caregiver education about disease trajectory, behavioral symptoms, and available support resources to prevent caregiver burnout
Mental health support for patient and caregivers; support groups for atypical parkinsonian disorders (CurePSP, AFTD)
Avoid sedating medications (anticholinergics, antihistamines, benzodiazepines beyond prescribed) that increase fall risk and cognitive impairment
Driving cessation: discuss early given asymmetric motor impairment, cognitive changes, and apraxia affecting reaction time and vehicle control

differential.features: Vertical gaze palsy; symmetric parkinsonism; early postural instability and falls; axial > limb rigidity
differential.tests: MRI (midbrain atrophy — "hummingbird sign"); clinical features (vertical gaze palsy, falls); symmetric presentation

differential.features: CBS presentation but underlying AD pathology (~25% of CBS cases); may be more symmetric; memory impairment may be more prominent
differential.tests: Amyloid PET (positive in AD-CBS); CSF biomarkers (low Aβ42, high p-tau); clinical course

differential.features: Personality change; disinhibition; apathy; compulsive behaviors; may overlap with CBS; GRN mutations can cause CBS
differential.tests: Neuropsychological testing (behavioral profile); MRI (frontal/temporal atrophy); genetic testing (GRN, MAPT, C9orf72)

differential.features: Rapidly progressive (weeks to months); myoclonus; periodic sharp waves on EEG; DWI restriction on MRI; CBS is a rare CJD presentation
differential.tests: MRI DWI (cortical ribboning); EEG (periodic complexes); CSF 14-3-3, RT-QuIC; rapid progression distinguishes

differential.features: Asymmetric but resting tremor prominent; good levodopa response; no cortical signs (apraxia, alien limb); slower progression
differential.tests: DaTscan (both abnormal); levodopa trial (PD responds well, CBS poorly); clinical features (tremor vs rigidity/apraxia)

differential.features: Cerebellar ataxia (MSA-C) or parkinsonism (MSA-P); autonomic failure; symmetric; no alien limb or apraxia
differential.tests: MRI (hot cross bun, putaminal changes); autonomic testing; symmetric presentation

differential.features: Fluctuating cognition; visual hallucinations; REM sleep behavior disorder; parkinsonism; levodopa-responsive
differential.tests: Clinical features (hallucinations, fluctuations, RBD); DaTscan; levodopa response

differential.features: May mimic CBS; inconsistent; distractible; positive functional signs (Hoover); onset may be abrupt
differential.tests: Clinical exam (inconsistency, distractibility, positive functional signs); normal imaging; psychiatric comorbidity

evidence.recommendation: Armstrong criteria for corticobasal degeneration and corticobasal syndrome diagnosis
CBS may be caused by multiple pathologies; ~25% have AD pathology
Levodopa trial recommended; poor response expected but partial benefit possible
Clonazepam effective for cortical myoclonus in CBS
Botulinum toxin for focal dystonia in CBS
FDG-PET shows asymmetric frontoparietal hypometabolism in CBS
evidence.source: [Pardini M et al. Eur J Nucl Med Mol Imaging 2019](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30554257/)

evidence.recommendation: Amyloid PET differentiates AD-CBS from non-AD CBS
Multidisciplinary care improves quality of life in atypical parkinsonian syndromes

monitoring.action: Adjust medications; botulinum toxin for focal dystonia; reassess myoclonus treatment
Adjust cholinesterase inhibitor if applicable; neuropsychological reassessment; advance care planning

monitoring.frequency: Q6 months or if symptoms change
monitoring.action: Speech therapy re-evaluation; diet modification; consider PEG tube if severe
PT reassessment; adaptive equipment; consider assistive devices; medication review for sedation
Adjust antidepressant or behavioral medication; psychiatry referral
Increase home health support; respite care; social work referral
Reduce dose or switch to alternative antimyoclonic agent
Dietary supplementation; assess swallowing; dietitian referral

disposition.criteria: Stable; no acute change requiring inpatient workup; no acute safety concern; outpatient neurology follow-up arranged
New presentation of rapidly progressive CBS requiring urgent workup (CJD exclusion); acute functional decline; aspiration pneumonia; inability to perform ADLs safely; caregiver crisis
Aspiration pneumonia with respiratory failure; status epilepticus from myoclonus (rare); acute medical complication
All patients: q3-6 months; more frequently during medication titration; advance care planning discussions at each visit
PT/OT/Speech: ongoing per functional needs; increase frequency as disease progresses
